raw_text: The work reported in Wu (1997), which uses an inside-outside type of training algorithm to learn statistical context free transduction, has a similar motivation to the current work, but the models we describe here, being fully lexical, are more suitable for direct statistical modelling

raw_text: The empirical adequacy of synchronous context-free grammars of rank two (2-SCFGs) (Satta and Peserico, 2005), used in syntax based machine translation systems such as Wu (1997), Zhang et al (2006) and Chiang (2007), in terms of what alignments they induce, has been discussed in Wu (1997) and Wellington et al (2006), but with a one-sided focus on so-called? inside-out alignments?

raw_text: We present a new method that exploits a novel application of Inversion Transduction Grammar or ITG expressiveness constraints (Wu 1995 [1], Wu 1997 [2]) for mining monolingual data to obtain tight sentence translation pairs, yielding accuracy significantly higher than previous known methods
clean_text: We present a new method that exploits a novel application of Inversion Transduction Grammar or ITG expressiveness constraints (Wu 1995 [1], Wu 1997 [2]) for mining monolingual data to obtain tight sentence translation pairs, yielding accuracy significantly higher than previous known methods.

raw_text: (Wu, 1997) introduced a polynomial-time solution for the alignment problem based on synchronous binary trees
clean_text: (Wu, 1997) introduced a polynomial-time solution for the alignment problem based on synchronous binary trees.

citing_paper_authors: Liang, Huang | Wenbin, Jiang | Qun, Liu
raw_text: Joint parsing with a simplest synchronous context-free grammar (Wu, 1997) is O (n6) as opposed to the monolingual O (n3) time
clean_text: Joint parsing with a simplest synchronous context-free grammar (Wu, 1997) is O (n6) as opposed to the monolingual O (n3) time.

raw_text: The Inversion Transduction Grammar (ITG) of Wu (1997) is a syntactically motivated algorithm for producing word-level alignments of pairs of transla tionally equivalent sentences in two languages
clean_text: The Inversion Transduction Grammar (ITG) of Wu (1997) is a syntactically motivated algorithm for producing word-level alignments of pairs of translationally equivalent sentences in two languages.

raw_text: The ITG we apply in our experiments has more structural labels than the primitive bracketing grammar: it has a start symbol S, a single preterminal C, and two inter me diate nonterminals A and B used to ensure that only one parse can generate any given word-level alignment, as discussed by Wu (1997) and Zens and Ney (2003)
clean_text: The ITG we apply in our experiments has more structural labels than the primitive bracketing grammar: it has a start symbol S, a single preterminal C, and two intermediate nonterminals A and B used to ensure that only one parse can generate any given word-level alignment, as discussed by Wu (1997) and Zens and Ney (2003).

raw_text: Wu (1997) demonstrated that for pairs of sentences that are less than 16 words, the ITG alignment space has a good coverage over all possibilities
clean_text: Wu (1997) demonstrated that for pairs of sentences that are less than 16 words, the ITG alignment space has a good coverage over all possibilities.

clean_text: Besides, our model, as being linguistically motivated, is also more expressive than the formally syntax-based models of Chiang (2005) and Wu (1997).
